title: China Eximbank provides RMB 370 million government concessional loan for Phase 1 of 90kV Dakar Electricity Distribution Network Rehabilitation and Extension Project (Linked to Project #138, #53177, and #53283)
description: On July 12, 2007, the Export-Import Bank of China and Societe Nationale d'Electricite du Senegal (SENELEC) — Senegal’s state-owned electricity company — signed an RMB 370 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Phase 1 of 90kV Dakar Electricity Distribution Network Rehabilitation and Extension Project.    This GCL carries the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and a 2% interest rate. This project involved the construction of a 27 kilometer, 90 KV high-voltage power transmission line and four 90/30 KV transformer substations in the city of Dakar. China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation (CMEC) was the contractor responsible for implementation.   The project's proposed start date was January 1, 2006, but work did not commence until September 28, 2007. Then, an official groundbreaking ceremony took place on January 21, 2009. The project was ultimately completed and accepted by the Government of Senegal on April 29, 2016.  As of September 23, 2016, China Eximbank had disbursed 26,026,772,582 XOF, leaving 9,973,227,418 XOF undisbursed. China Eximbank also financed the second phase of this project (see Project ID#53283) and provided supplemental funding through a third loan (see Project ID#53178). The first phase of this project was funded by China Eximbank and it is captured in Project ID#138.  This project is also known as Phase 1 of the 90kv Dakar Power Loop Transmission and Power Grid Project and Phase 1 of Dakar City Power Transmission and Transformation Project. The Chinese project title is 塞内加尔达喀尔环城输变电项目 or 惠贷款的环达喀尔输变电项目. The French project title is 1ère phase de boucle 90 kV de Dakar or 1ère phase de Boucle de Dakar. China Eximbank also provided two follow-on loans to support this project (see Project ID#53178 and ID#53283). In the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020, it does not report the terms of the loan (20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 2% interest rate) that supported this project. AidData relies upon the borrowing terms that are reported by the borrower: Societe Nationale d'Electricite du Senegal (SENELEC).
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 370 million government concessional loan for Phase 1 of 90kV Dakar Electricity Distribution Network Rehabilitation and Extension Project (Linked to Project #138, #53177, and #53283)

# Description
On July 12, 2007, the Export-Import Bank of China and Societe Nationale d'Electricite du Senegal (SENELEC) — Senegal’s state-owned electricity company — signed an RMB 370 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Phase 1 of 90kV Dakar Electricity Distribution Network Rehabilitation and Extension Project.    This GCL carries the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and a 2% interest rate. This project involved the construction of a 27 kilometer, 90 KV high-voltage power transmission line and four 90/30 KV transformer substations in the city of Dakar. China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation (CMEC) was the contractor responsible for implementation.   The project's proposed start date was January 1, 2006, but work did not commence until September 28, 2007. Then, an official groundbreaking ceremony took place on January 21, 2009. The project was ultimately completed and accepted by the Government of Senegal on April 29, 2016.  As of September 23, 2016, China Eximbank had disbursed 26,026,772,582 XOF, leaving 9,973,227,418 XOF undisbursed. China Eximbank also financed the second phase of this project (see Project ID#53283) and provided supplemental funding through a third loan (see Project ID#53178). The first phase of this project was funded by China Eximbank and it is captured in Project ID#138.  This project is also known as Phase 1 of the 90kv Dakar Power Loop Transmission and Power Grid Project and Phase 1 of Dakar City Power Transmission and Transformation Project. The Chinese project title is 塞内加尔达喀尔环城输变电项目 or 惠贷款的环达喀尔输变电项目. The French project title is 1ère phase de boucle 90 kV de Dakar or 1ère phase de Boucle de Dakar. China Eximbank also provided two follow-on loans to support this project (see Project ID#53178 and ID#53283). In the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020, it does not report the terms of the loan (20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 2% interest rate) that supported this project. AidData relies upon the borrowing terms that are reported by the borrower: Societe Nationale d'Electricite du Senegal (SENELEC).
justification: Project focuses on electricity distribution network rehabilitation and extension, which is essential infrastructure but does not directly contribute to energy transition
evidence: Construction of 27km 90KV high-voltage power transmission line and four transformer substations in Dakar

title: 12th medical team dispatched to Pikine National Hospital Center
description: On April 9, 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of Senegal signed an agreement related to the dispatching of the 12th Chinese medical team to Senegal.  China has been sending medical teams to Senegal since 1975. China stopped sending medical teams for 10 years (after Senegal severed diplomatic ties with it), but then dispatched the 12th medical team in 2007 after Senegal re-established diplomatic ties with China. All of the Chinese medical teams that have been dispatched to Senegal are from Fujian Province. The 12th medical team included 16 members and it was stationed at the Pikine National Hospital Center in Dakar. It completed its terms of service between September 2007 and September 2009.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
12th medical team dispatched to Pikine National Hospital Center

# Description
On April 9, 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of Senegal signed an agreement related to the dispatching of the 12th Chinese medical team to Senegal.  China has been sending medical teams to Senegal since 1975. China stopped sending medical teams for 10 years (after Senegal severed diplomatic ties with it), but then dispatched the 12th medical team in 2007 after Senegal re-established diplomatic ties with China. All of the Chinese medical teams that have been dispatched to Senegal are from Fujian Province. The 12th medical team included 16 members and it was stationed at the Pikine National Hospital Center in Dakar. It completed its terms of service between September 2007 and September 2009.
justification: Project involves medical team dispatch for healthcare services, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team dispatch to hospital, healthcare focus, no energy or infrastructure components

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Tivaouane Peul Primary School Construction Project
description: In July 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of Senegal signed a grant agreement for a Primary School Construction Project. The proceeds from this grant agreement were earmarked for the construction of multiple primary schools in the Dakar Region. This grant commitment was recorded in the Government of Senegal’s External Financing Management Platform (la Plateforme de Gestion des Financements Extérieurs du Sénégal, or PGFE), but its monetary value of the commitment was not identified.  Ultimately, the proceeds from this grant agreement were only used to support the construction of a single primary school in the village of Tivaouane Peul. The Tivaouane Peul Primary School Construction project was officially completed and handed over to the authorities on July 29, 2016. Then, on October 4, 2016, an opening ceremony was held for the school.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Primary School Construction Project. The French project title is écoles primaires de la région de Dakar. The Chinese project title is 中国援塞小学校项目 or Tivaouane Peul小学.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Description

The proceeds from this grant agreement were earmarked for the construction of multiple primary schools in the Dakar Region. This grant commitment was recorded in the Government of Senegal’s External Financing Management Platform (la Plateforme de Gestion des Financements Extérieurs du Sénégal, or PGFE), but its monetary value of the commitment was not identified.  Ultimately, the proceeds from this grant agreement were only used to support the construction of a single primary school in the village of Tivaouane Peul. The Tivaouane Peul Primary School Construction project was officially completed and handed over to the authorities on July 29, 2016. Then, on October 4, 2016, an opening ceremony was held for the school.
justification: Project is focused on education infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Primary school construction, education sector focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 180 million grant for Museum of Black Civilizations Construction Project
description: In January 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Senegal signed letters of exchange related to the Museum of Black Civilizations Construction Project. The Chinese Government committed RMB 180 million of grant funding for this project. This project involved the construction of a four-story building on a 2.2 hectare site with a total construction area of 14,665 square meters.   The building has a flat cylindrical shape, and it includes exhibition halls, ceremonial halls, digital projection halls, and offices. The purpose of the museum is to highlight "Africa's contribution to the world's cultural and scientific patrimony." Shanghai Construction Engineering Group was the contractor responsible for project implementation. It signed a project implementation contract with the Government of Senegal in November 2011. Then, on December 20, 2011, a ceremonial foundation-laying ceremony was organized. However, construction did not begin until December 20, 2013. Senegal’s Ministry of Culture (Ministère de la Culture et de la Communication) originally anticipated that the project would take 28 months to complete, but the project was ultimately completed and handed over to the authorities on January 25, 2016. The museum was opened to the public on December 6, 2018. The museum is directed by Hamady Bocoum, an archaeologist and researcher at University Cheikh-Anta-Diop.
staff_comments: The French project title is Musée des Civilisations Noires. The Chinese project title is 塞内加尔黑人文明博物馆.”  The Museum of Black Civilizations (or Musée des Civilisations Noires) is located in the capital city of Dakar. It is geographically adjacent to the Grand National Theater. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/496182485.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 180 million grant for Museum of Black Civilizations Construction Project

# Description
In January 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Senegal signed letters of exchange related to the Museum of Black Civilizations Construction Project. The Chinese Government committed RMB 180 million of grant funding for this project. This project involved the construction of a four-story building on a 2.2 hectare site with a total construction area of 14,665 square meters.   The building has a flat cylindrical shape, and it includes exhibition halls, ceremonial halls, digital projection halls, and offices. The purpose of the museum is to highlight "Africa's contribution to the world's cultural and scientific patrimony." Shanghai Construction Engineering Group was the contractor responsible for project implementation. It signed a project implementation contract with the Government of Senegal in November 2011. Then, on December 20, 2011, a ceremonial foundation-laying ceremony was organized. However, construction did not begin until December 20, 2013. Senegal’s Ministry of Culture (Ministère de la Culture et de la Communication) originally anticipated that the project would take 28 months to complete, but the project was ultimately completed and handed over to the authorities on January 25, 2016. The museum was opened to the public on December 6, 2018. The museum is directed by Hamady Bocoum, an archaeologist and researcher at University Cheikh-Anta-Diop.
justification: Project is focused on cultural infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Museum construction project, cultural and educational purpose, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 390 million government concessional loan for Phase 1 of E-Government Project (Linked to Project ID#58409 and ID#53282)
description: On September 10, 2007, China Eximbank and the Government of Senegal signed an RMB 390 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 1 of the E-Government Project. Phase 1 established data, voice, and video conference systems for government agencies, universities, hospitals and other state-owned enterprises and institutions by laying 500 km of fiber optic cable — in Dakar, Thiès, Louga, Saint Louis, Diourbel, Kaolack and Fatick — and created data centers to support the e-government network (also known as the government intranet).   It also involved the creation of a fixed, IP, and mobile telephony network covering 11 regional capitals, including Dakar, Thiès, Louga, Saint Louis, Diourbel, Kaolack, Fatick, Matam, Tambacounda. Huawei (中国华为公司) and China Machinery Engineering Corporation (中国机械设备进出口公司) were responsible for implementation. Construction began on December 12, 2007 and the Phase 1 was officially completed and handed over to the authorities on July 10, 2009. Then, in January 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of Senegal signed a $50 million loan agreement for Phase 2 of the E-Government Project. This loan reportedly carried the following terms: a 20 year maturity and 2.75% interest rate.  Phase 2, which began in December 2012 and ended in late 2014, involved an expansion of the country’s national fiber optic backbone and administrative intranet. More specifically, it involved the laying of 1,000 additional kilometers of fiber optic cable in Mbour, Bignona, Sédhiou, Tambacounda, Koungueul, Kaffrine, Kaolack, Fatick, Tamba, Kolda, Vélingara, Ziguinchor, Saint-Louis, Louga, Diourbel, and Blaise Diagne International Airport (AIBD). Huawei was responsible for the implementation of Phase 2.    Then, on November 24, 2015, China Eximbank and the Government of Senegal signed an RMB 530 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 3 of the E-Government Project. The terms of this loan are unknown, As of February 19, 2019, total disbursements through this loan amounted to 33,377,043,667 FCFA. Phase 3 involved the laying of 2,565 additional kilometers of fiber optic cable and the construction of a 4x400 m2 data center in Diamniadio. It sought to link 300 administrative buildings, 21 departmental capitals, and 2 regions (Kédougou and Matam). Huawei was the contractor responsible for implementation of Phase 3. Construction began in January 2016 and the project achieved a 70% completion rate by the end of the same year. Phase 3 was eventually completed, but the precise completion date is unknown. The China Eximbank loan that supported Phase 1 is captured in Project ID#58382, while the China Eximbank loan that supported Phase 2 is captured in Project ID#58409 and the China Eximbank loan that supported Phase 3 is captured in Project ID#53282.   This project was also known as Phase 1 of the E-Government Fiber Optic and Administrative Intranet Project. The French project title is Phase 1 du Projet E-Gov. The Chinese project title is 一期光纤网目 or 塞内加尔电子政务网络 or Phase I一期光纤网.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 390 million government concessional loan for Phase 1 of E-Government Project (Linked to Project ID#58409 and ID#53282)

# Description
On September 10, 2007, China Eximbank and the Government of Senegal signed an RMB 390 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 1 of the E-Government Project. Phase 1 established data, voice, and video conference systems for government agencies, universities, hospitals and other state-owned enterprises and institutions by laying 500 km of fiber optic cable — in Dakar, Thiès, Louga, Saint Louis, Diourbel, Kaolack and Fatick — and created data centers to support the e-government network (also known as the government intranet).   It also involved the creation of a fixed, IP, and mobile telephony network covering 11 regional capitals, including Dakar, Thiès, Louga, Saint Louis, Diourbel, Kaolack, Fatick, Matam, Tambacounda. Huawei (中国华为公司) and China Machinery Engineering Corporation (中国机械设备进出口公司) were responsible for implementation. Construction began on December 12, 2007 and the Phase 1 was officially completed and handed over to the authorities on July 10, 2009. Then, in January 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of Senegal signed a $50 million loan agreement for Phase 2 of the E-Government Project. This loan reportedly carried the following terms: a 20 year maturity and 2.75% interest rate.  Phase 2, which began in December 2012 and ended in late 2014, involved an expansion of the country’s national fiber optic backbone and administrative intranet. More specifically, it involved the laying of 1,000 additional kilometers of fiber optic cable in Mbour, Bignona, Sédhiou, Tambacounda, Koungueul, Kaffrine, Kaolack, Fatick, Tamba, Kolda, Vélingara, Ziguinchor, Saint-Louis, Louga, Diourbel, and Blaise Diagne International Airport (AIBD). Huawei was responsible for the implementation of Phase 2.    Then, on November 24, 2015, China Eximbank and the Government of Senegal signed an RMB 530 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 3 of the E-Government Project. The terms of this loan are unknown, As of February 19, 2019, total disbursements through this loan amounted to 33,377,043,667 FCFA. Phase 3 involved the laying of 2,565 additional kilometers of fiber optic cable and the construction of a 4x400 m2 data center in Diamniadio. It sought to link 300 administrative buildings, 21 departmental capitals, and 2 regions (Kédougou and Matam). Huawei was the contractor responsible for implementation of Phase 3. Construction began in January 2016 and the project achieved a 70% completion rate by the end of the same year. Phase 3 was eventually completed, but the precise completion date is unknown. The China Eximbank loan that supported Phase 1 is captured in Project ID#58382, while the China Eximbank loan that supported Phase 2 is captured in Project ID#58409 and the China Eximbank loan that supported Phase 3 is captured in Project ID#53282.   This project was also known as Phase 1 of the E-Government Fiber Optic and Administrative Intranet Project. The French project title is Phase 1 du Projet E-Gov. The Chinese project title is 一期光纤网目 or 塞内加尔电子政务网络 or Phase I一期光纤网.
justification: Project focuses on digital infrastructure development for government and public institutions without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Fiber optic cable installation, data centers, government intranet development, no direct energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government donates 50 Hongqi vehicles worth $2.2 million (Linked to Project ID#58553)
description: In 2007, the Chinese Government donated 50 Hongqi (红旗) or "red flag" luxury vehicles to the Government of Senegal. The monetary value of this donation is unknown. However, in 2010, the Chinese Government donated 50 Hongqi vehicles to the Government of Senegal and the estimated monetary value of this donation was $2,286,531.90 (see Project ID#58553).

title: Chinese Government cancels CFAF 3.5 billion of the Government of Senegal’s outstanding debt obligations
description: Prior to the Government of Senegal severing its diplomatic ties with the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in 1996, it obtained an interest-free loan from the (PRC). Then, in 2007, after a resumption of diplomatic ties between the two countries, the PRC agreed to cancel the Government of Senegal’s outstanding debt obligations (worth CFAF 3.5 billion) that resulted from this interest-free loan.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government cancels CFAF 3.5 billion of the Government of Senegal’s outstanding debt obligations

# Description
Prior to the Government of Senegal severing its diplomatic ties with the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in 1996, it obtained an interest-free loan from the (PRC). Then, in 2007, after a resumption of diplomatic ties between the two countries, the PRC agreed to cancel the Government of Senegal’s outstanding debt obligations (worth CFAF 3.5 billion) that resulted from this interest-free loan.
justification: Debt cancellation is a financial service with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Cancellation of CFAF 3.5 billion debt obligations, financial transaction focus
